title: Add sortOrder to CreateProjectInput and UpdateProjectInput
Add client-side filtering to list_projects
description:
## Problem
All projects returned regardless of relevance. User may have many archived/closed projects.

## Solution
Add filtering parameters to `list_projects` tool:

```typescript
// Filter parameters
closed?: boolean           // Filter by archived status (default: false = active only)
kind?: 'TASK' | 'NOTE'     // Filter by project type
viewMode?: ViewMode        // Filter by view mode
search?: string            // Text search in project name
limit?: number             // Max results
```

## Default Behavior
By default, only return active (non-closed) projects to reduce noise.

title: Implement POST /batch/task endpoint (batch_create_tasks)
description:
Implement the MCP tool to create multiple tasks in a single API call.

**Inputs:**
- `tasks` (array, required): Array of task objects to create. Each task object can have:
  - `title` (string, required): Task title
  - `projectId` (string, optional): Project ID (defaults to inbox)
  - `content` (string, optional): Task description/notes
  - `allDay` (boolean, optional): Whether this is an all-day task
  - `startDate` (string, optional): Start date in ISO 8601 format
  - `dueDate` (string, optional): Due date in ISO 8601 format
  - `timeZone` (string, optional): IANA timezone (e.g., "America/New_York")
  - `reminders` (array of strings, optional): Reminders in iCalendar format
  - `repeat` (string, optional): Recurrence rule in RRULE format
  - `priority` (number, optional): 0=None, 1=Low, 3=Medium, 5=High
  - `items` (array, optional): Subtask/checklist items

**Outputs:**
Returns an array of created Task objects, each containing:
- `id` (string): Unique task identifier
- `projectId` (string): Parent project ID
- `title` (string): Task title
- `content` (string): Task description
- `priority` (number): Priority level
- `status` (number): 0=Normal, 1=Completed
- `dueDate` (string | null): Due date
- `startDate` (string | null): Start date
- `tags` (array of strings): Tags
- And other task fields

**Description:**
This endpoint allows creating multiple tasks in a single API request. This is more efficient than making individual create requests when adding many tasks at once.

**API Endpoint:** POST /batch/task

**Request Body Format:**
```json
{
  "add": [
    { "title": "Task 1", "projectId": "project_id", "priority": 1 },
    { "title": "Task 2", "projectId": "project_id", "priority": 3 }
  ]
}
```

**Tool Name:** batch_create_tasks

**Implementation Notes:**
1. Add `batchCreateTasks` method to the SDK client (src/sdk/client.ts)
2. Add MCP tool wrapper in src/index.ts
3. Consider adding validation for minimum/maximum batch size
4. Consider rate limiting implications for large batches

title: Implement GET /project/{projectId} endpoint (get_project_by_id)
description:
Implement the MCP tool to get a project by ID without including its tasks.

**Inputs:**
- `projectId` (string, required): The unique identifier of the project to retrieve

**Outputs:**
Returns a Project object with the following fields:
- `id` (string): Unique project identifier
- `name` (string): Project name
- `color` (string): Hex color code (e.g., "#ff6b6b")
- `sortOrder` (number): Position in project list
- `closed` (boolean): Whether project is archived
- `groupId` (string | null): Parent folder ID
- `viewMode` (string): "list", "kanban", or "timeline"
- `kind` (string): "TASK" or "NOTE"

**Description:**
This endpoint retrieves a specific project by its ID without including tasks. Unlike `get_project` which uses `GET /project/{projectId}/data` and returns both project and tasks, this provides a lightweight way to fetch just the project metadata.

**API Endpoint:** GET /project/{projectId}

**Tool Name:** get_project_by_id

**Notes:**
- The existing `get_project` tool uses the `/data` variant which includes tasks
- This tool should be used when only project metadata is needed

API docs specify Task kind can be: TEXT, NOTE, CHECKLIST (line 736).
Code only defines `TaskKind = "TEXT"` (types.ts:43).

## Solution

```typescript
export type TaskKind = "TEXT" | "NOTE" | "CHECKLIST";
```

title: Create AI-friendly Priority enum with descriptive names
Add list_tasks_in_project convenience tool
description:
Add a convenience MCP tool to list all tasks in a specific project.

**Inputs:**
- `projectId` (string, required): The unique identifier of the project

**Outputs:**
Returns an array of Task objects with the following fields for each task:
- `id` (string): Unique task identifier
- `title` (string): Task title
- `content` (string): Task description
- `priority` (number): 0=None, 1=Low, 3=Medium, 5=High
- `status` (number): 0=Normal, 1=Completed
- `dueDate` (string | null): Due date
- `startDate` (string | null): Start date
- `tags` (array of strings): Tags
- `items` (array): Subtasks

**Description:**
While `get_project` returns tasks along with project metadata, this tool provides a focused way to list just the tasks in a project. This is useful when the user only needs task information and already has the project details.

**API Endpoint:** GET /project/{projectId}/data (same as get_project, but returns only tasks)

**Tool Name:** list_tasks_in_project

**Implementation Notes:**
1. Uses the existing `getProjectWithTasks` SDK method
2. Returns only the `tasks` array, not the project object
3. Consider adding optional filter parameters in future (status, priority, date range)

title: Add 'get_tasks_due_soon' convenience tool
description:
## Problem
AI often needs to find tasks due in the next N days. Currently requires fetching all tasks across all projects.

## Solution
Create a new `get_tasks_due_soon` tool:

```typescript
// Parameters
days?: number              // Tasks due within N days (default: 7)
includeOverdue?: boolean   // Include past-due tasks (default: true)
projectId?: string         // Optional: limit to specific project
status?: 'active' | 'all'  // Default: 'active' (exclude completed)
```

## Implementation
1. Fetch all projects
2. For each project, fetch tasks via /project/{id}/data
3. Filter to tasks with dueDate within range
4. Sort by dueDate ascending
5. Return consolidated list with project name included

## Output
```json
{
  "success": true,
  "count": 5,
  "tasks": [
    { "title": "...", "dueDate": "...", "projectName": "Work", ... }
  ]
}
```

This saves multiple round-trips and significant tokens.

title: Implement POST /project/{projectId} endpoint (update_project)
description:
Implement the MCP tool to update an existing project's properties.

**Inputs:**
- `projectId` (string, required): The unique identifier of the project to update
- `name` (string, optional): New project name
- `color` (string, optional): New hex color code (e.g., "#ff6b6b")
- `viewMode` (string, optional): New view mode - "list", "kanban", or "timeline"
- `kind` (string, optional): New project type - "TASK" or "NOTE"

**Outputs:**
Returns the updated Project object with the following fields:
- `id` (string): Unique project identifier
- `name` (string): Project name
- `color` (string): Hex color code
- `sortOrder` (number): Position in project list
- `closed` (boolean): Whether project is archived
- `groupId` (string | null): Parent folder ID
- `viewMode` (string): "list", "kanban", or "timeline"
- `kind` (string): "TASK" or "NOTE"

**Description:**
This endpoint allows updating an existing project's properties. Only the fields that are provided will be updated; other fields remain unchanged.

**API Endpoint:** POST /project/{projectId}

**Tool Name:** update_project

**Implementation Notes:**
1. Add `updateProject` method to the SDK client (src/sdk/client.ts)
2. Add MCP tool wrapper in src/index.ts
3. Validate that at least one field is provided for update

title: Create tickets for every TickTick API endpoint
description:
Once OAuth is working, create individual tickets for implementing each TickTick API endpoint in the MCP server.

Each endpoint ticket must include:
- **Inputs** - All parameters, their types, and whether required/optional
- **Outputs** - Response structure and data types
- **Description** - What the endpoint does

Goal: Full coverage of the TickTick API.

Add client-side sorting to list_tasks_in_project
description:
## Problem
Tasks are returned in API default order. AI may need to request all tasks then mentally sort, wasting tokens.

## Solution
Add sorting parameters to `list_tasks_in_project` tool:

```typescript
sortBy?: 'dueDate' | 'priority' | 'title' | 'createdTime' | 'modifiedTime' | 'sortOrder'
sortDirection?: 'asc' | 'desc'  // Default: 'asc'
```

## Smart Defaults
- `sortBy: 'dueDate'` with `sortDirection: 'asc'` shows urgent tasks first
- Null dates sorted to end

## Example
```json
{
  "projectId": "abc123",
  "sortBy": "priority",
  "sortDirection": "desc"
}
```
Returns high priority tasks first.

Enhance update_task tool with missing parameters
description:
Enhance the update_task MCP tool to support all available API parameters.

**Currently Implemented Parameters:**
- `taskId` (string, required)
- `title` (string, optional)
- `content` (string, optional)
- `dueDate` (string | null, optional)
- `priority` (number, optional)
- `tags` (array, optional)

**Missing Parameters to Add:**
- `projectId` (string, optional): Move task to a different project
- `allDay` (boolean, optional): Whether this is an all-day task
- `startDate` (string | null, optional): Start date in ISO 8601 format or null to remove
- `timeZone` (string, optional): IANA timezone (e.g., "America/New_York")
- `reminders` (array of strings | null, optional): Reminders in iCalendar TRIGGER format or null to clear
- `repeat` (string | null, optional): Recurrence rule in RRULE format or null to remove
- `items` (array, optional): Array of subtask/checklist items

**Description:**
The current update_task implementation only supports basic task fields. This ticket adds support for moving tasks between projects, updating scheduling (startDate, allDay, timeZone), reminders, recurring tasks, and subtasks/checklists.

**Implementation Notes:**
1. Update Zod schema in src/index.ts to include new optional parameters
2. Ensure SDK client passes all fields correctly
3. Document that null values can be used to clear optional fields

title: Add client-side filtering to list_tasks_in_project
description:
## Problem
When listing tasks, the full list is returned, consuming many tokens for AI processing. The TickTick API doesn't support server-side filtering.

## Solution
Add client-side filtering parameters to `list_tasks_in_project` tool:

```typescript
// Filter parameters
status?: 'active' | 'completed' | 'all'  // Default: 'all'
priority?: Priority | Priority[]         // Filter by priority level(s)
dueBefore?: string                        // ISO date - tasks due before this date
dueAfter?: string                         // ISO date - tasks due after this date
startBefore?: string                      // ISO date
startAfter?: string                       // ISO date
hasSubtasks?: boolean                     // Only tasks with/without subtasks
tags?: string[]                           // Filter by tags (any match)
search?: string                           // Text search in title/content
limit?: number                            // Max results to return
```

## Implementation
1. Fetch all tasks from API
2. Apply filters in order
3. Return filtered subset

## Token Savings
A project with 100 tasks returning ~50KB could be filtered to 10 relevant tasks (~5KB) = 90% token reduction.

title: Fix field naming: repeatFlag vs repeat in Task type

## Problem
API docs use `repeatFlag` for recurrence rules (lines 120, 161, 731), but code uses `repeat` in Task interface (types.ts:148).

## Solution
Rename `repeat` to `repeatFlag` in Task interface and all related types to match API docs.

title: Add 'search_tasks' tool for cross-project text search
description:
## Problem
AI needs to find tasks by keyword across all projects. No API endpoint exists for this.

## Solution
Create `search_tasks` tool:

```typescript
// Parameters
query: string              // Required: search term
searchIn?: ('title' | 'content' | 'desc')[]  // Default: ['title', 'content']
projectIds?: string[]      // Optional: limit to specific projects
status?: 'active' | 'completed' | 'all'
caseSensitive?: boolean    // Default: false
limit?: number             // Default: 20
```

## Implementation
1. Fetch tasks from specified projects (or all)
2. Search text fields for query match
3. Return matching tasks with relevance context

## Output includes match context
```json
{
  "tasks": [{
    "id": "...",
    "title": "Review **meeting** notes",  // highlight match
    "matchedIn": ["title"],
    "projectName": "Work"
  }]
}
```

Document undocumented API endpoints: /user and /batch/task
description:
## Problem
Code implements endpoints not in the provided API docs:
1. `GET /open/v1/user` - Get current user info
2. `POST /open/v1/batch/task` - Batch create tasks

These work in practice but aren't officially documented.

## Solution
1. Add internal documentation noting these are undocumented endpoints
2. Consider adding disclaimer in JSDoc comments
3. Update docs/TICKTICK_API.md with these endpoints and note their undocumented status

```typescript
/**
 * Get the current authenticated user's information.
 * 
 * @remarks This endpoint is not officially documented in the TickTick Open API
 * but is functional and commonly used.
 */
async getUser(): Promise<User>
```

title: Add ViewMode enum for better type safety
Create AI-friendly TaskStatus enum with named values
Fix Task status completed value (2 not 1)
description:
## Problem
API docs specify Task status Completed=2 (line 734), but code enum has Completed=1 (types.ts:27).

Note: ChecklistItem status Completed=1 is correct per API docs.

## Solution
Create separate enums for Task and ChecklistItem status:
- `TaskStatus`: Normal=0, Completed=2
- `ChecklistItemStatus`: Normal=0, Completed=1

This is critical as it will cause tasks to not be properly marked complete.

title: Extract batch_create_tasks tool to src/tools/batchCreateTasks.ts
Document TickTick API authentication and endpoints
description:
Review the TickTick OpenAPI documentation at https://developer.ticktick.com/docs#/openapi and document:

1. **Authentication** - How does auth work for this API?
2. **Endpoints** - What endpoints are available?
3. **Data flow** - What data goes where and comes from where?

This research will inform the MCP server implementation.

title: Extract delete_project tool to src/tools/deleteProject.ts
Add ProjectKind enum for better type safety
Add 'get_high_priority_tasks' convenience tool
description:
## Problem
Common AI query: "What are my most important tasks?" Requires fetching everything.

## Solution
Create `get_high_priority_tasks` tool:

```typescript
// Parameters
minPriority?: Priority     // Default: Priority.Medium (3)
projectId?: string         // Optional: limit to project
includeCompleted?: boolean // Default: false
limit?: number             // Default: 10
```

## Implementation
1. Fetch tasks (all projects or specified)
2. Filter by priority >= minPriority
3. Sort by priority desc, then dueDate asc
4. Return top N tasks

Quick, focused response for priority queries.

title: Build TickTick SDK from API documentation
description:
Using the API documentation created in ticktick-mcp-2, build a TypeScript SDK for interacting with the TickTick API.

The SDK should:
- Handle authentication
- Provide typed methods for all documented endpoints
- Include proper error handling
